newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadair workers seek new contract talks.
newsitem.headline: Canadair workers seek new contract talks.

text.p: Workers at Bombardier Inc's Canadair aerospace unit are seeking new contract talks after voting 61 percent against the company's latest offer on the weekend.
"We want to negotiate a new offer," Jean-Leo Cote, spokesman for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, told Reuters on Monday.
Cote said he was waiting to hear from company officials on whether new talks were possible. Canadair officials were in meetings on Monday and not immediately available for comment.
Union members voted 61 percent against Canadair's latest offer on Sunday. The offer had been accepted by the union executive.
The union represents 4,700 workers at Canadair's Montreal plant which makes the company's 50-seat Regional Jet. About 3,600 members voted on Sunday.
In March, union members voted 96 percent in favour of giving their leadership a strike mandate. Cote said another vote would have to be held to reaffirm that strike mandate.
"A strike would be our last option," Cote said.
Workers are upset with the five-year length of the proposed contract and a pilot project under which certain members would work 12-hour shifts without overtime pay.
